quote: If he has a hard day, we're all gonna have a hard day.

I did read someone's recap on it from last year via a friend on Strava and it resembled what you said: Basically climb for 20-30 minutes of rough gravel, descend down rough gravel, go through sand, do it again 3-4 times.

Turns out that the race was A) really hard, B) I was still really life-tired, or C) both. During post-race beer commiseration, MTB legend and IMBA president Dave Wiens assured me the answer was A, which made me feel moderately better.
The scenery over the 120-mile course was staggeringly beautiful, with early hints of autumn blushing in the hills and terrain that ranged from 'pedaly' to fast to downright chunder.
I personally like to run tires that are wide, grippy and robust, rather than pushing the rubber reliability envelope in the name of marginal speed gains.
I always bring a rain shell, gloves, and a beanie just in case.

Covering 119 miles over two days is a demanding endeavor. However, around 80 miles of the route consist of well-graded and well-maintained gravel roads, leaving riders with only 33 miles of two-tracks, routes, and steep roads to navigate.

With the majority of the route is relatively easy technical riding, but there are a few sections, specifically towards the end, where the roads get challenging enough that you may need to jump off your bike.

The day we rode, conditions ran the gamut, from buttery smooth road to molar-loosening braking bumps, to one narrow road section near the end of the main climb that was littered with softball-size embedded rocks.
Some of these roads receive little to no maintenance and can change drastically after heavy rains and/or snowfall.
This route is rated as a 6 out of 10 for overall difficulty if ridden as an overnighter. Stretch it to three days and that goes down a notch or two.

Another factor to consider is the higher altitude, which might pose a challenge for folks coming from out of state, as they'll likely feel the effects of the elevation. It's worth noting that Gunnison itself sits at 7,700 feet.
Altitude, sun exposure, storm potential, and two long days in the saddle will certainly leave you tired at the end of the trip.
During post-race beer commiseration, MTB legend and IMBA president Dave Wiens assured me the answer was A, which made me feel moderately better.
The Gunni Grinder has the potential to become a marquee race.
We spent all of our vacation time for more than two years riding, driving, studying maps and running into lots of dead-ends and roads that were just a little too challenging for a gravel event...
A portion of the race profit helps support Gunnison Trails
